articles.title: Most States Now Require Tech Competence for Lawyers. What Does That Mean For You?
articles.description: Legal ethics rules in a majority of states now require attorneys to become and remain familiar with technologies that affect their practices. States across the country have begun to provide more specific guidance as to what these ethical duties entail, giving lawyers specific examples that may apply directly or analogously to the technologies they use every day.

articles.title: Trump Immigration Order Affects Moot Court
articles.description: While pundits and commentators knew that the effects of President Trumpâ€™s executive order restricting immigration to the United States would have far-reaching effects, one potentially unexpected consequence was on an international moot court competition. Two teams, one from Iran and one from Iraq, will almost surely not be able to attend the prestigious Jessup International Moot Court Competition in April due to the order.

articles.title: Jury Awards Ousted General Counsel Nearly $8M; Metadata is Said to Be Important Evidence
articles.description: A San Francisco jury awarded nearly $8 million to a whistleblower after he showed that a negative performance review was actually created after his firing date, as indicated by metadata associated with the performance review.
